title: Liz #3 [Early Colored Liz]
transcript:
NARRATOR: This group of works is the core of the Edlis/Neeson Collection and perhaps the finest collection of Andy Warhol paintings in any encyclopedic museum.

For Warhol, content and process went hand-in-hand. Starting in the early 1960s, he turned to mass culture to find images for his paintings…and used a mass market technique—the photomechanical silkscreen—to transfer those images onto canvas. Director James Rondeau.

JAMES RONDEAU: The advantage of seeing works of art by Andy Warhol in a single room is you see not only the range of his practice, but a thread of an idea that runs through.

So, there are images that seem to be overtly beautiful and glamorous, and on the other hand, there are images that seem to be very much about trauma and violence.

NARRATOR: In some cases, he combined them both—such as selecting an image of Jackie Kennedy after her husband’s assassination, or, in his portrait of Elizabeth Taylor.

JAMES RONDEAU: We maybe lose the context from the early 1960s where Liz Taylor was as much a picture about disaster as about glamour. Warhol, for instance, began working with Liz’s image only after he found a newspaper photograph of her being carried off an airplane in a hospital gurney with pneumonia, near death.

NARRATOR: As you see here, no subject was sacred. And with silkscreening, he could easily manipulate color and play with repetition until an image was often rendered nearly meaningless.

JAMES RONDEAU: There’s a kind of leveling effect where Warhol is saying, “Celebrities are the same as tragedy; banal images of beauty are the same as death and disaster; objects are the same as people.” Almost everything is the same.
